entry.title: Răspuns: Personal opinion on the fee market from a worried local trader
entry.summary: The topic of discussion is the role of transaction fees in Bitcoin mining. A member of the bitcoin-dev community questioned the incentive for miners to include transactions for free, stating that it was akin to asking for money. Another member points out that while fees currently make up less than 0.8% of a miner's revenue, they should be compared to profit margin instead. For example, if a miner invests/spends 24 BTC per block and earns 0.25 in fees, then fees comprise 20% of their profit. While profit margins are currently high, this may change as more investors enter the market and competition increases, driving down profit margins. The post includes hypothetical calculations to illustrate how fees can become more significant over time. For instance, if a block costs 5 BTC in 2015 and brings in 0.25 in fees, fees account for 1.2% of total profit. However, if BTC appreciates and competition increases, resulting in a cost of 6 BTC per block, fees could make up 4% of total profit. By mid-2020, when another halving occurs and the subsidy decreases, fees could account for 100% of a miner's profit. While these estimates are rough, they show that fees can quickly become important under pressure from factors such as halving, growing valuation, and mining competition.
